Pendle Borough Council paid £37,800 to four suppliers that were in active breach of Companies House requirements — all rated as high severity. While this is the cleanest record of the three East Lancashire councils, the nature of the breaches is still concerning.

The Four Suppliers

Supplier Paid During Breach Issue
Marston (Holdings) Ltd£17,100Filed dormant accounts but receiving payments
Jewson Ltd£17,000Filed dormant accounts but receiving payments
Auto Match Ltd£3,400Confirmation statement overdue; filed dormant but receiving payments
Fourth supplier£300Companies House breach

The "Dormant But Active" Problem

The most common pattern among Pendle's non-compliant suppliers is companies that have filed dormant accounts at Companies House while still receiving council payments. This is a significant red flag.

A dormant company is one that has had no "significant accounting transactions" during the financial year. If a company is receiving thousands of pounds from a council, it is by definition not dormant. Filing dormant accounts while trading is potentially:

  • A breach of the Companies Act — dormant accounts are a simplified filing option only available to genuinely inactive companies
  • Tax avoidance — dormant companies have different tax obligations, so filing dormant accounts while trading could reduce tax liability
  • A sign of poor governance — the company may not have adequate financial controls

Marston (Holdings) Ltd: £17,100

Marston (Holdings) Ltd is the enforcement arm used by many councils for council tax and parking fine collection. The company filed dormant accounts while receiving payments from Pendle — suggesting either a corporate restructuring issue or a filing error. Either way, a council should verify the status of companies it contracts with for enforcement services.

Jewson Ltd: £17,000

Jewson is a well-known building materials supplier. Again, dormant accounts were filed while the company received payments. Given Jewson is part of the Saint-Gobain group, this may reflect a holding company structure issue — but the council should still verify which entity it is actually contracting with.

How Pendle Compares

At £37,800, Pendle's exposure is a fraction of Hyndburn's £1.1 million. This suggests either better supplier vetting practices or simply a different supplier mix. Either way, the council deserves credit for having the cleanest compliance record — while still needing to address the four cases identified.
